title: Rapman 3mm Filament guide clip / generic clip

description.text:
This is a filament guide/clip or can be used as a generic wire clip to hold your wires out of the way.
I wanted a clip that I did not have to feed the filament through when loading the printer but can be added/removed or adjusted while the printer is running. 
Hole for filament/wire is 5mm to not cause too much resistance.
Clip is for 15mm diameter tubing (but works if a little bigger or smaller)

Print and use.
Tested with PLA
The clip can also be used as a generic clip, I found it is useful as a generic wire clip to hold wires out of the way.

author: mfarchitetti

title: Picavet for 2 liter bottle aerial photography

description.text: A design for adding a picavet (suspension system/gimble) to the pop bottle camera mounts at http://www.publiclaboratory.org/wiki/pet-bottle-rubber-band-rig The design uses bicycle chain links as low-friction pulleys. You can use a M3 or 4/40 eye bolt instead Weight with zip ties & 4 pulleys is 34grams (mark 5 design)

As of 8/12, this design has not had a lot of field testing. The ideal arm length may be slightly shorter (or longer) 1) Find a laser cutter, a bicycle chain braker tool, and a length of scrap bike chain. Most shops will give you the chain for free.
2) Select the version you want to try. Version 5 is light and fine for holding the camera, but will break if you drag it on the ground. Version 7 attempts to make it slightly more rugged.
3) Cut the design. 6mm plywood seems to be the best for strength.
4) Remove every other pin from your length of chain. Each pulley is made from one set of links: there will be one pin, which holds the outside 2 plates, the inside 2 plates, and the roller.
5). Fold the plates so they all over lap, and keep the bottom roller between the inner plates. Your pulley is the part with the pin.
6) Thread a zip tie through the bottom hole, but don't zip it yet.
7) Squeeze the bottom of a pulley into the square hole towards the tip of the cross. All pulleys have the pins pointing the same way.
8) Zip tie the pulley to the picavet, using the notches and holes provided.
9) Push the center of the picavet over the threads of a 2 liter bottle. Not all bottles are the same size, so you might have to scrape off some wood or plastic.
10) Use a pin or knife to make a small hole under 2 opposite arms of the picavet.
11) Use string or fine copper wire (#24 picture wire works well) to thread through the 2 holes you just made in the bottle. Push the ends of the wire through the holes or notches in the picavet. This is how your camera stays attached to the kite, so make sure you've lashed things together well. Try not to obstruct the neck of the bottle too much, since your camera mount needs to pass through.
12) String the picavet using the instructions from http://www.kaper.us/basics/BASICS_picavet.html . Use one of the left over chain bushings as the central washer. When you mount the camera, instead of mounting to a notch in the bottle, use one or more of the notches on the picavet. You can also knot the camera safety cord through one of the loops on the arm. Thanks to Celaya for the clever pulley idea.
  • You can use the bottle cap to screw on this picavet. But this requires a hole in the cap for the camera mounting. You'd probably want to glue or tape the cap on.

comments.text: I love the 'bicycle chain link pulley' idea!

description.text:
This is a simple Windows-based application that estimates the weight and price of objects you print on your 3D printer. You supply it with the quantity of filament used (from gCode, etc), the type of material, the material diameter, and the price per kilogram. The application will then estimate the weight and cost of the print. If you want to estimate the cost of multiple prints, just put in a quantity and the application will give you the bulk printing information as well.
The application has support for ABS, PLA, PVA, and HDPE at the moment. Due to slight variations in material density, conditions,etc. the calculation is not 100% accurate. In my tests, it has been accurate to within about 2-3 grams.
I have provided the source below if anyone wants to port it to another platform.

Download the installer below and run it.
To find out how much filament is required for a model, open up the gcode file for the model and scroll all the way to the bottom. Look for the last entry in the file that begins with the letter E. It may look something like this:
G1 E26477.211
Plug this number (26477.211) into the length field of the 3d calculator, and fill out the rest of the fields in the dialog box. Hit calculate to get the weight and cost estimates. 
You can open multiple calculation windows to see which material is more cost effective for a given print, etc. The application will warn you if your objects exceed 1kg.

comments.text: does anybody know how can I calculate the printing time? I am lost =(
comments.author: jassizorr

comments.text: I don't think there is a very accurate way to calculate print times, unfortunately. Every brand of printer is going to have different print firmware and hardware, so a print that takes 3 hours on one machine might be faster or slower on another. With accelerated printing, it becomes less-possible to determine the print speed, as the print planner on the printer is constantly calculating the speed for the next printer move. In a lot of cases, the accelerated print planner will slow down the print head to maintain quality. So, there are just too many variables to account for.
comments.author: jassizorr

comments.text: how can I view my G code to determine the final length? (I'm on windows xp)
comments.author: rothe22

comments.text: It depends on which slicer you're using. If you're using RelicatorG, then there is a tab in the app which shows you the g-code after your object has been sliced. You can then just click on Instructions above and use those instructions. I haven't made the jump to Makerware, so I'm not sure how to get the info from there.  Other slicers usually output gCode at some point in the slicing cycle, so if you're using one of those, you might have to do some google searching to figure out where the gCode is being stored. Once you have the gCode, though, you can use the same instructions that I provided for ReplicatorG.

comments.text: I'm actually working on a new application that will allow you to enter custom filament densities, along with a lot of other cool featueres. You can probably expect it within the next month or two. In the meantime, the density of PVA and Polycarbonate in cubic centimeters is really close---1.19 for PVA and 1.20 for polycarbonate. So, you should  be able to get very close to the correct result by choosing PVA.

comments.text: I have been using your program for some time, but I gave a try to a different one and the calculations are different, can you tell the difference?
comments.author: agumbrella

comments.text: It looks like the other app is not taking any factors into account, other than the volume of the triangles making up the object. My calculator is taking the actual nozzle extrusion values from the gcode, so it accounts for different fill ratios, different fill types, extra shells, etc., because those moves have already been calculated by the slicer.

comments.text: I measure power consumption of a batch (full bed of 1 part) on a Kill-A-Watt meter to get total Kw consumption per batch. It would be nice to have this option even if the cost is considered minimal as it can add up over the course of multiple batches run.
comments.author: funkykartracer

comments.text: I played around with the numbers for the Replicator, and in a worst case situation(where it was drawing maximum power the whole time), it might cost 2-4 cents an hour to operate where I live. The problem is that it takes a lot less power to maintain the heat in the extruders and platform than it does to initially heat them up. So, it's really hard to calculate. I can hook up my Kill-A-Watt and do some averages over several prints, but that would only be useful for Replicator users. I think the cost added is negligible unless you are doing 20 hour prints all the time. Even then, it might only add $0.25 to the price of the part.
comments.author: funkykartracer

comments.text: Love this thing!
comments.author: delsydsoftware

comments.text: Yeah, I can provide the source a bit later today.  I need to put better comments in the source before I release it , but that really shouldn't take too long. The math behind it is really simple, though. I'm just figuring the area for a cylinder (pi times the radius squared) with the radius of the filament and the length provided. To get the weight, you multiply this times the density of the material in cubic milimeters. Figuring the cost of the part is just a matter of dividing the 1kg roll price by 1000(to get the price per gram), then multiplying that result times the weight in grams.
comments.author: danielpublic

description.text: This is an adapter for using new J-Head Mk V-B hotend in the printrbot v2. Due to this hotend is smaller than others, the X-carriage hits the bed. I made this derivative for lower the pb-Xtruder-Mount-v2 and print correctly with the hotend. NOTE: This piece may be helpful for using with another small hotend, but I can't test it.

Print this piece if you have a small hotend. This piece will be inserted between the pb-Xtruder-Mount-v2 and the pb-X-Carriage-v2, both official parts of the Printrbot. You need three M4 bolts and three nuts. Two bolts should be 40mm long and the other 15 or 20mm long.
